conclusion: Understand the path of light through wedge-shaped glass using Snell's law and properties of triangles.
The top angle of the wedge is 30 degrees and the refraction angle is 45 degrees.
Snell's law: n1 * sin(theta1) = n2 * sin(theta2), where n1 and n2 are indices of refraction, theta1 and theta2 are angles of incidence and refraction.
Angle of incidence when light enters the glass is 45 degrees.
Angle of incidence when light leaves the glass is 60 degrees.
Light travels in a straight line in the glass and reflects off the sides, forming a triangle with the sides of the wedge.
Angle of incidence and angle of reflection are related by properties of the triangle and the wedge.
Ratio of lengths is given by the ratio of sines of angles involved in the triangle formed by the path of light.
Calculate the ratio: sin(45 degrees)/sin(30 degrees) = sqrt(2).
The ratio of the length of the light-emitting part on the edge to the length of the edge is sqrt(2).
